content: The "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007" establishes the Independent Ethics Commission. The Independent Ethics Committee, established within the House of Representatives, consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader for 5-year terms. Commissioners must be former Federal judges. The Independent Ethics Committee appoints 9 commissioners for 5-year terms, who must be former Federal judges. Only former Federal judges are eligible for appointment to the Commission, with disqualifications for lobbyists and members of Congress. Vacancies on the Commission will be filled as needed. The Commission appoints 9 former Federal judges for 5-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members receive compensation based on Level III of the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings. Meetings are called by a majority of members. The Commission appoints 9 former Federal judges for 5-year terms and compensates them based on Level III of the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, which are called by a majority of members. The Commission is authorized to receive, monitor, and oversee financial disclosure and other reports, investigate alleged violations of conduct rules by Members, officers, and employees of the House, present ethics violation cases to the Committee on Standards, and make recommendations to the Committee. The Commission oversees financial disclosure reports, investigates conduct rule violations, and provides guidance to Members, officers, and employees of the House on rules and standards of conduct. The House of Representatives provides guidance and advisory opinions to its Members, officers, and employees on rules and standards of conduct, subject to review by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, under Section 4, has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, issue subpoenas with majority approval, request information from government agencies, and refer matters to the Department of Justice. The Commission can conduct general audits of filings under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 and refer potential violations to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 5. INVESTIGATIONS AND INTERACTION WITH THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. The Commission must notify the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct when initiating an investigation. The committee has the authority to overrule the Commission's determination within 10 legislative days with a two-thirds majority vote and must provide a public report explaining their decision. If the Commission decides to investigate and its decision is not overturned, it will conduct an investigation to determine if a violation occurred. During the investigation, the Commission can administer oaths and issue subpoenas. The Commission has the authority to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, compel witness testimony and documents, and take witness depositions. Failure to comply with subpoenas or testify may result in contempt of Congress. If the Commission finds probable cause of an ethics violation, it notifies the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct for further action. The committee can overrule the Commission with a two-thirds majority vote, issue a public report explaining the decision, include each member's vote in the report, and allow dissenting members to issue their own report. If overruled, the Commission can publish a report on why it presented the case. If the Commission finds probable cause of an ethics violation and its decision stands, the case is presented to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives for a determination. The committee votes on whether the individual violated any rules, with a roll-call vote and dissenting members can issue their own report. Whenever the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives finds an ethics violation, the Commission recommends sanctions and may refer the matter to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 6. PROCEDURAL RULES. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on House members, officers, or employees' official conduct. Investigations can only be initiated by the Commission upon receipt of a written complaint under oath from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct chairman. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on House members, officers, or employees' official conduct. Investigations can only be initiated by the Commission upon receipt of a written complaint under oath from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct chairman. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives prohibits investigations of alleged violations of laws, rules, regulations, or standards not in effect at the time of the alleged violation. Information or testimony received by the Commission cannot be publicly disclosed without specific authorization by a vote of the Commission. The Commission may appoint staff as necessary, paid at a rate not exceeding Level III of the Executive Schedule. Amendments to the House rules may change the duties of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. House Rules Amendments: Clause 3 of rule XI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by striking and redesignating subparagraphs, amending paragraph (b)(1) by removing certain text, and striking various paragraphs. Conforming Amendments are made to the Ethics Reform Act. The Ethics Reform Act of 1989 is amended by removing subsections (c) and (d) in a conforming amendment. SEC. 9. ACTION ON COMMISSION RECOMMENDATIONS. Upon receipt of a report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives will have it printed in the Congressional Record. Within 14 days of the report being printed, any recommendations for action regarding alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House will be introduced in the House by the Speaker and the minority leader. Resolution introduced by the Speaker of the House and the minority leader constitutes a question of privilege under House rules. Members can call up the resolution as a question of privilege three days after announcing their intention to do so. The Act will take effect upon enactment, with exceptions for sections 3, 4, and 8 which will not take effect until noon on January 3, 2009.
